posts_data.title: GOLD - in pictures
posts_data.content: GOLD - captured by Paul Verhagen, live from the 013 venue, Tilburg. April 16, 2021.

posts_data.title: Roadburn Deep Dive - Neurosis
posts_data.content:
“Roadburn gave us all a home.”


José Carlos Santos takes a deep dive with Steve Von Till, looking back at the 30th anniversary shows that Neurosis played back in 2016; what they mean to the band, what they meant to Walter - and the impact they had on the festival as a whole.

posts_data.title: The Nest's special guests revealed
posts_data.content:
Wolvennest - who play tomorrow as The Nest - have confirmed the special guests that will be joining them for their commissioned project, titled Her True Nature.

AA Nemtheanga (Primordial, Dread Sovereign)

Tommie Eriksson (Saturnalia Temple)

Bones (Dread Sovereign)

Alexander von Meilenwald (The Ruins Of Beverast)

Ryanne van Dorst (DOOL).


The Nest perform tomorrow at 22.50 CEST - live from the 013 venue, Tilburg.

posts_data.title: Album Premiere: Regarde Les Hommes Tomber performing Ascension
posts_data.content: We absolutely loved Regarde Les Hommes Tomber’s 2020 album Ascension - so we asked if they’d be up for performing the whole dang thing for us - and for you - as part of Roadburn Redux. They said yes! Their intoxicating amalgam of genres is about to be brought to life especially for Roadburn Redux.

posts_data.title: Algiers - 73%
posts_data.content:
When Algiers agreed to contribute something to Roadburn Redux we didn’t know what we were due to receive. But this is a band that we adore so wholeheartedly that we’d have gladly accepted just about anything they threw at us. What was sent our way was a brand new track in the form of a video collage which we’re delighted to share with you today. If you like what you hear and you want to show some love to one of the most exciting bands we’ve fallen in love with in recent years then you can do so via Bandcamp or Patreon. 


Here's what Franklin James Fisher told us about the track:


"So what is 73 percent? What is it supposed to represent? Is it political allegory? Is it a new manifesto disguised as a song? Who are the 73 percent? Well, if these questions distract you beyond a passing curiosity and beseech immediate protest action or an urgency to take up arms, a quick dive into a search engine could probably provide some sort of satiating meaning. For example: 

-73 percent of Republican voters questioned the legitimacy of Joe Biden’s victory over Trump in the 2020 American presidential election. 

-Misinformation online dropped by 73 percent after Trump’s Twitter account was suspended.

-73 percent of consumers say they’re willing to pay more for a product that promises total transparency.

-73 percent of workers consider health and wellness offerings when considering a job.

-Traffic congestion dropped 73 percent in 2020 due to the pandemic. 

-Et cetera...

But this song literally refers to none of these things. If it did, better to just throw out the music altogether and instead publish an essay fulminating against 1,2,3 and demanding ABCs of varying shapes and sizes.

Sometimes the mumbling soothsayer on the sidewalk has more insight than the town cryer on the soapbox.

We hope you enjoy the entertainment."
